snippet: Almost invisibly in her own day, Natalie de Blois, of Skidmore, Owings & Merrill, helped guide the design of three of the most important corporate landmarks of the 1950s and ’60s.
abstract: Profile of recently deceased architect Natalie de Blois, who worked almost invisibly at Skidmore, Owings & Merrill during the 1950s and 1960s, guiding design of at least three important corporate landmarks in Manhattan; de Blois's contributions are being touted by the Beverly Willis Architecture foundation, which seeks to raise awareness of the contributions of women in the building industry.
lead_paragraph: Almost invisibly in her own day, Natalie de Blois, of Skidmore, Owings & Merrill, helped guide the design of three of the most important corporate landmarks of the 1950s and ’60s.

headline.main: An Architect Whose Work Stood Out, Even if She Did Not
headline.print_headline: An Architect Whose Work Stood Out, Even if She Did Not
